command: Invoke-Command -ScriptBlock { $mac = '00:11:22:33:44:55'; $b = ($mac -replace '[:\-]','') -split '(..)' | Where-Object { $_ } | ForEach-Object { [Convert]::ToByte($_,16) }; $packet = New-Object System.Collections.Generic.List[byte]; 1..6 | ForEach-Object { [void]$packet.Add(0xFF) }; 1..16 | ForEach-Object { $b | ForEach-Object { [void]$packet.Add($_) } }; $udp = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.UdpClient; $udp.Client.SetSocketOption([Net.Sockets.SocketOptionLevel]::Socket,[Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName]::Broadcast,$true); $udp.Connect('192.168.1.255',9); [void]$udp.Send($packet.ToArray(), $packet.Count); $udp.Close() }
explanation: Sends a standard Wake-on-LAN magic packet (6x0xFF + 16 repetitions of the MAC). This is a traffic signal to wake a sleeping host, aligning with T1205. Detection: monitor for unexpected UDP broadcasts to port 9 with 102-byte payloads containing repeated MACs; baseline approved WOL usage per VLAN. No elevated privileges required for sending; UAC not triggered.
rationale_steps: Construct WOL magic packet with correct 102-byte format.
Broadcast UDP on port 9 to signal a remote device to wake (traffic signaling).
Note monitoring recommendations for unusual WOL bursts from admin workstations.
